TopicTitle: Science recovery, how it works exactly?

Articles.Content:
Hi guys, actually i'm a kind of "old" player (about 2 years and half of playing constantly KSP) but only recently i switched to career mode. Changing to this has opened to me the world of science in KSP, now i have a question, if you want to return 100% of the experiment is necessary to land on kerbin the mistery goo or materials bay? There isn't another way? How science recovery works?

Thanks, Daze

Goo and Mat bays take 3 (or 4, if you're going whole hog, but the 4th is minimally useful) fully returned to Kerbin for max science. Thus the idea of 'science bombs' which you send out, use, and then send home on a suicide burn with chutes.

EDIT: With a Science Lab, you can store multiple reports of the same experiment for return. So, if you're being frugal, you can take a Kerbal on EVA, load everything up into that, and send just the lab home.

You can also transmit crew reports and EVAs for 100%, but otherwise yes, returning the experiment to Kerbin is the only way (either in the original container, or in a science lab or capsule or whatever)
How is possible to make it on a realistic way? Ex. I put all esperiment on Mk1-2 pod than i do a reentry on kerbin

How is possible to make it on a realistic way? Ex. I put all esperiment on Mk1-2 pod than i do a reentry on kerbin

Go on EVA, go up to the experiments, right click, click "take data", go back to the command pod

Also be aware that a pod can hold only one result per (experiment + situation + biome). So one Goo from the Midlands and one from the Highlands will be OK; but if you want to return two from the midlands, you need to bring two pods, or one lab (currently the only stock module that can hold duplicate results), or the science container (mod part).

No you don't need to use a scientist. The mobile lab requires a lot of power to run, but otherwise it's just a case of right clicking it and pressing the buttons.

You have to actually run the experiment first The science lab can be used to reduce the penalty from transmitting science (but it does need to be manned) or to clean an experiment that has been used to allow it to be used again . Both operations consume a significant amount of power and may take a while to process if there's a lot of experiments.
